Award.AwardTitle: Geometric Evolution of Multicomponent Amphiphilic Networks
Award.AbstractNarration:
The development of efficient energy conversion and storage devices is a fundamental goal of 21st century science. Many of the most prominent devices, such as dye-sensitized and bulk-heterojunction solar cells, lithium ion batteries, and polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells, rely upon ionomer membranes with charge-selective transport properties that arise from nanoscale networks of charge-lined pores. Progress in the improvement of these devices requires new materials based upon a fundamental understanding of the formation of these pore networks, which typically self-assemble during casting processes. The investigator presents a mathematical framework that characterizes the evolution of network morphologies arising in blends of charged polymer (amphiphile) with solvent. A better understanding of how these networks shape themselves can enable the development of better devices. The framework is based upon an incorporation of the powerful descriptive properties of dynamical systems within a higher-order free energy landscape. Students are trained in the course of the project.

The Functionalized Cahn-Hilliard (FCH) free energy unites the languages of dynamical systems and calculus of variations to produce a model of network self-assembly in amphiphilic polymers that play a central role in the cost-efficient self-assembly of materials with nano-structured interfacial morphology. The investigator studies the mechanisms of geometric evolution and competition-induced bifurcation of network morphologies of binary and multicomponent amphiphilic systems within the framework of gradient flows of the FCH free energy. For binary mixtures of amphiphilic polymer and solvent, the investigator analyzes the pearling bifurcation induced by competition between codimension one bilayer morphologies and codimension two pore morphologies. Rigorous existence of pearled morphologies for curved codimension one interfaces are derived via spatial dynamics center manifold reduction, and rigorous sharp-interface reductions of FCH gradient flows to mass-preserving Willmore flows via renormalization group techniques are pursued. End cap and line defects play a significant role in the evolution of network morphologies, and the investigators characterizes reduced representations for these defect structures and quantifies their impact on roll-up of bicelles (a bicelle is a flat bilayer with an end-cap boundary). For multicomponent mixtures, the investigator follows three approaches to the bilayer existence problem: a novel billiard limit involving a piece-wise smooth potential with sharp transitions, a homomorphic reduction, and a singular perturbation limit. Each approach permits explicit construction of coexisting symmetric and asymmetric bilayer morphologies, and an analysis of the resulting bifurcation structure. The investigator derives a sharp-interface competitive geometric evolution for families of distinct, coexisting bilayer networks and a non-zero intrinsic curvature limit for asymmetric bilayers subject to non-gradient form perturbations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Amphiphilic polymers are composed of long chains repeated chemical units, some of which (hydrophilic components) mix strongly with a solvent and some of which mix poorly (hydrophobic components) with the solvent. When placed in a solvent the polymers self-assemble into structures that segregate the hydrophobic components, predicting the forms the polymers will take requires a detailed understanding of the energetics of the packings of polymer and solvent which is strongly predicated upon the aspect ratio of the hydrophilic and hydrophobic components, the strength of the electrostatic interactions that drive the hydrophilicity and hydrophobicity, and the overall polymer chain length. The functionalized Cahn-Hilliard (FCH) free energy presents an energy landscape that incorporates a wide range of polymer-solvent configurations including codimension one layers (interfaces), codimension two filaments (strings), codimension three micelles (dots), and various defect structures such as Y-junctions and endcaps that have no well-defined codimension.

 

Intellectual Merit: NSF-DMS grant 1409440, entitled ?Geometric Evolution of Multicomponent Amphiphilic Networks? used mass-preserving gradient flows of the FCH to model the evolution of amphiphilic polymer morphologies that transpire as a dispersion of polymer is stirred into a solvent bath. One of the key results, ?Competitive geometric evolution of amphiphilic interfaces,? SIAM Math. Analysis (2015), with Shibin Dai, characterized the slow evolution of families of codimension one and codimension two structures within a solvent bath. Through multiscale analysis of the weak scaling of the FCH free energy, the PI showed that these structures enter into a competition for the amphiphilic polymers which are loosely dispersed within the bulk of the solvent; each codimension has its own insertion and extraction rate by which polymers join or leave the structure, and these rates depend upon the spatially constant density of the polymer dispersed within the bulk solvent. In effect the codimensional structures that can achieve net growth (insertion dominates extractions) at the lowest bulk value will out-compete the other and eventually be the last structure standing. The PI and collaborators show that the shape of the structures is governed by a Willmore type flow that transitions from a curve lengthening to a curve shortening regime based upon the common bulk value of the dispersed polymer.

 

A major factor in determining the eventual shape of dispersions of polymer in solvent resides with the possibility of the assembled structures to pearl ? develop periodic variations in the width of the structure that can lead to perforation. For example, a spherical bilayer, which resembles a beach ball, can pearl so that its surface becomes dimpled like that of a golf ball, or can completely perforate to resemble a whiffle-ball.  In ?Existence of pearled patterns in the planar Functionalized Cahn-Hilliard equation,? J. Differential Equations (2015), with Q. Wu, we used a detailed normal form calculation within the spatial dynamics reduction for the fourth order system to show that the onset of pearling leads to stable morphologies with the weakly pearled (dimpled), see Figure 1. In ?Existence, bifurcation, and geometric evolution of quasi- bilayers in the multicomponent functionalized Cahn-Hilliard Equation,? Journal of Mathematical Biology (2017), with Q. Wu, the PI and collaborator extended this analysis to multicomponent bilayers composed of two distinct types of amphiphilic polymer.  Showing in addition that the internal structure of the two polymer components dictates that composition of the bilayer, and can result in a phase separation in which the inner and outer leaflets of the bilayer are composed of one or other of the pure phases, and the value of the bulk polymer density can determine if one or the other of the bilayers will pearl, see Figure 2 for a comparison of experimental and simulated results. In submitted work, ?Competition and Complexity in Amphiphilic Polymer Morphology?, with A. Christlieb and N. Kraitzman, the PI and collaborators show that the interaction of pearling with transient growth can predict the onset of experimentally observed morphological complexity in polymer casting, see Figure 3.

 

Broader Impact: The proposal resulted in the training of two graduate students and one postdoctoral fellow. The graduate students include two women: Noa Kraitzman who received her PhD from MSU in 2015 and is currently the NSF Ed Lorenz Postdoctoral Fellow at the University of Utah, and Hayirie Guckir, who is a current graduate student. The postdoctoral fellow, Qiliang Wu, became a tenure system faculty member at Ohio University in 2016. Two undergraduate research groups trained on semester-long projects related to the proposal, one in spring semester 2014 and a second in fall semester 2016. The work of the PI generated over 750 citations (google scholar) during the granting period, and generated a collaboration with a plant biologist, Prof. Federica Brandizzi, that resulted in follow-up funding for both PIs.
